title: Huge Oscars mix-up as La La Land wrongly named best picture winner before Moonlight | London Evening Standard
text:
Dramatic moment bus is engulfed in flames after 'explosion' 
The Oscar for best picture was awarded to the wrong film in an extraordinary gaffe on stage at the awards in Hollywood last night. 
Actors Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway were due to announce the winner, which should have been Moonlight, but in an unprecedented mix-up, they were handed the wrong card. 
A clearly flustered Beatty hesitated before handing the card to Dunaway who read out the name of La La Land, to rapturous applause. 
However the La La Land card was for the award Best Actress in a Leading Role. The card for best actress in a leading role in the hand of Warren Beatty 
Stars of La La Land flooded the stage in anticipation of receiving the best picture award. 
Emma Stone, Ryan Gosling and producers Jordan Horowitz and Marc Platt even went so far as to begin their acceptance speeches. Producer Jordan Horowitz sets the record straight and announces that Moonlight has won Best Picture 
Meanwhile panicked producers were seen running around backstage after it became clear something had gone wrong. Warren Beatty Academy Awards Oscars Gaffe 2017 Warren Beatty Academy Awards Oscars Gaffe 2017 1/14

Producer Jordan Horowitz then appeared and told a stunned crowd: "There's a mistake. Moonlight you guys won best picture. This is not a joke, Moonlight you won best picture. Moonlight best picture." Confusion: Producers intervene as the La La Land team are on stage (Lucy Nicholson/Reuters ) 
Platt added: "This is no joke I'm afraid they read the wrong thing." 
Horowitz then held up a card towards the camera showing Moonlight had won best picture while the film's cast and crew were shown hugging in jubilation. 
Oscar host Jimmy Kimmel intervened, saying: "This is very unfortunate what happened," before joking: "Personally I blame Steve Harvey" in a jibe at Harvey announcing the wrong winner at Miss Universe in 2015. 
Horowitz said: "I'm going to be really proud to hand this to my friends to Moonlight" and hugged the film's star Mahershala Ali. 
As La La Land's flummoxed crew cleared the stage, Beatty returned to the microphone and said: "I'll tell you what happened. I opened the envelope and it said 'Emma Stone La La Land' that's why I took such a long look at Faye and then you. I wasn't trying to be funny. This is Moonlight, best picture." 
Exactly how the blunder came about is unclear. 
Emma Stone insisted she was holding the best actress envelope "the entire time" and said the La La Land team were in a "state on confusion". 
Speaking backstage, Stone said:"I also was holding my best actress in a leading role card that entire time. I don't mean to start stuff but whatever story that was - I had that card. So I'm not sure what happened.

Just days ago vote counters Brian Cullinan and Martha Ruiz said such a mistake was near impossible. 
The pair who hold the cases containing the winners’ names and are the only people who know who is receiving statuettes, explained last week what would happen if the wrong name was read out. 
Martha told Huffington Post: “It’s him checking me and me checking him, and we do it multiple times against each other to make sure that when we leave and are ultimately handing the envelopes to someone, we’re very confident they’re getting the right envelopes and the contents in them are accurate.” 
While Brian added that such a mistake had never been made during the ceremony, so the exact procedure on how it would be rectified is unknown. 
Casey Affleck beat Denzel Washington, Ryan Gosling and Andrew Garfield to win Best Actor his role in Manchester By The Sea, despite being plagued by sexual abuse allegations in the past few weeks. 
Paying tribute to fellow nominee Washington, Affleck said: “One of first people who taught me how to act was Denzel Washington & I just met him tonight for first time.”

Stone told the crowd that the story of the struggling actress emulated her own and thanked co-star Ryan Gosling for “being the greatest partner on this crazy adventure.” 
The self-deprecating star added: “'A moment like this is a huge confluence of luck and opportunity.” John Travolta just called to congratulate Warren Beatty, as our nation celebrates the peaceful transfer of power btwn biggest Oscar Screwups — Darren Criss (@DarrenCriss) February 27, 2017 Who else is hoping Warren Beaty is going to go to Washington DC and doing the same thing with the ballots from our presidential election? — Derek Blasberg (@DerekBlasberg) February 27, 2017 the way mans snatched that card out of Warren Beatty's hand lmaoooo the enthusiasm behind the snatch — Hanif Abdurraqib (@NifMuhammad) February 27, 2017 
Damien Chazelle became the youngest ever filmmaker in history to win the Best Director prize for La La Land at the age of 32. 
Viola Davis brought the house down with her emotional acceptance speech after being named winner of the Best Supporting Actress prize for her role in Fences. 
“People ask me all the time, what kind of stories do you want to tell, Viola? And I say, exhume those bodies, exhume those stories, the stories of the people who dreamed,” she said. Moonlight trailer 
“I became an artist, and thank god I did, because we are the only profession that celebrates what it means to live a life. So here’s to August Wilson, who exhumed and exalted the ordinary people.” Best dressed at The Oscars 2017: LIVE from the red carpet 
Davis also made history as the first black star to pick up acting awards at the Oscars, Emmys and Tony Awards. 
Mahershala Ali became the first Muslim actor to win an Oscar for his role as a supporting actor in Barry Jenkins’ acclaimed coming of age drama, Moonlight. 
“I had so many wonderful teachers, and one thing that they consistently told me ... was it wasn’t about you, it’s not about you. It’s about these characters,” he said on stage. Read more
